												Defcon simply put is perhaps the most brutal yet elegant strategy game you will ever play. While the game only supports 1 map, little gamemodes and very little unit choice, this opens a whole new realm of micromanagement/strategy where games can be won in a matter seconds. I could go for a whole page critically examining the intricate depths of Defcon strategy and how intense but fantastic it is, but honestly I find the mood of Defcon speaks for itself......"The Defcon counter slowly counts down to DEFCON 2, as you manoeuvre your subs to deliver a fatal first strike to Asia. The slow hum of a massive turbine and background radio remind you of a massive nuclear bunker, where deep underground you are determining how many people die from your orders. The slow strings of a cello pass the time, as you anxiously wait for DEFCON 1.......3.........2...........1........the massive letters of DEFCON 1 flash across the screen along with a high pitched siren.Suddenly you spring into action clicking on your subs, activating your dormant SLBM's methodically targetting the major cities across the Asian continent. A quiet piano beings to play but you don't realise it when your too busy concentrating. As you finish the last of your targets another warning signal blares and a small nuclear signal flashes on top of your sub. The SLBM's slowly fire up, then gracefully turn towards their targets. Satisfied you take a break and nervously watch the SLBM's fall down as a now louder piano plays sombre, dark notes......flash......Tokyo hit....4 million dead.....success your first SLBM hits the target dead on, soon after the entire coast of Asia is alight with bright flashes and messages.....Beijing hit.....Honk Kong hit......8 million dead.....6 million dead. As the last of the SLBM eradicate the last survivors you glance at the scoreboard, excellent you are leading by 50 points. Content you move over to your Pacific fleet to co-ordinate your bombers to deliver another fatal attack on Asia and as you again click on further targets with deadly precission you hear the faint coughs of a woman along with the humming of the loud turbines. Horrified you realise how clean and elegant the deaths you have been presented with. A flash, a confirmation and a number killed. Reality brings you back as you further witness the extermination of the rest of Asia, the whole continent  glows brightly as ALBM's rain upon the cities illuminating the world map.Despairingly you imagine yourself deep underground, ordering the death of an entire population by a simple click and you don't even see their deaths. Only a small flash and a number killed.

												It's amazing what can be accomplished with a handful of previously used concepts and carefully balanced rules. DEFCON: Everybody Dies, the latest title from UK-based Introversion Software, places you in the middle of your very own nuclear bunker, planning the demise of the world above. Surprisingly enough, the most attractive aspect of this game is its simplicity. A single glance at a screenshot will quickly illustrate that this isn't a graphics-intensive game which, like so many on a nearby retail shelf, incite purchases with incredibly realistic rendering.DEFCON is like a game of chess with a deadly spin: a series of units is placed on a pre-defined map and a set of strategic actions take place. However, when the king falls, more than half of the world's population has been killed. As the website suggests, it's not about winning, it's about losing the least. The game divides the world into six territories  which are pitted against each other in an epic struggle of who will press the big red button first.Since the rules of the game are so easy to understand, anybody can quickly join in on the mayhem. As the game timer advances, the DEFCON level increases, changing the combat options of the players.The key element to this game, which Introversion has expertly mastered, is maintaining the atmosphere. No dramatic music is queued when launching your nukes, no explosions challenge your subwoofer when a city is vaporized, and no screams are heard when a few million people die. DEFCON highlights just how easy it is to ignore the painful deaths of half the world's population when you're safely hidden in an underground bunker somewhere, plotting the demise of the enemy.DEFCON has a fairly nice presentation. Both the game's manual and website are built on a very fitting template made to look like a 50 year-old booklet which hasn't been touched since the end of the cold war. The manual reads fairly easily, in part due to the simplicity of the game.The auditory elements of DEFCON are limited at best. The game's atmosphere thrives on solemn low-volume music which just barely breaks an otherwise dreary silence. Whilst the tracks themselves are fairly good and appropriate, most gamers won't really notice unless they really crank up the volume.DEFCON is clearly intended to be played against human players. The variety of tactics and strategies that make this game challenging can only come from human minds. The AI is still respectably intelligent though, if you're not quite ready to challenge real players.Simply put, it's an amazing game. It could be argued that the appeal is limited, as after all, there is only one map to play on. But due to shifting alliances and perceived threats, the game never fails to feel anything but completely fresh.An interesting concept, classic battle graphics and tremendous replayability, this game has it all.

												DEFCON, in simple terms, is a simulator/game where you can destroy entire countries and continents by using nuclear weapons to decimate populations and cities whilst watching them burn. You can choose to be either North America (Canada, USA), South America (All South American countries), Africa (All African countries), Asia (Most Asian countries and far east countries), Europe (All European countries) or just Russia (Just russia, duh). There is a DEFCON timer, in which it starts from DEFCON 5 all the way to DEFCON 1, signalling nuclear war. The DEFCON system is a US defence and readiness condition system in which state the military should be readied at, depending on the current condition, five to one. Slowly or very quickly depending on what speed you want it on, the DEFCON level will drop until it reaches DEFCON 1 and nuclear war will begin. The game is based on a film called Wargames (1983) and is about a hacker who gains control of NORAD's nuclear missiles and threatens nuclear war. The GUI and game is very similar to Wargames' control systems and computer simulations. In order to start the game you need to select one of the continents, you can place down radars, missile silos and airbases. Each one of these has a certain strategic importance. Radars can detect incoming nuclear missiles from nuclear submarines or land based silos and show their trajectories. Airbases have the ability to launch fighter and bombers to city targets or fleets of ships in the oceans, the bombers can also drop one nuke onto a city or military target. Silos obviously have the ability to fire up to 10 missiles anywhere at a target. Silos can also become air defence systems in which they will shoot down incoming missiles, fighters and bombers within their range. There is also the ability to place fleets of ships (nuclear missile equipped submarines, battleships and aircraft carriers). Submarines can attack ships on the surface of the sea and sink them and can also fire nukes at cities within a shorter range than silos but they are more stealthy. Battleships are an all-round ship, they can attack all kinds of ships including aircraft. Aircraft carriers can launch nuke bombers to cities or military targets and attack them and launch fighter jets to attack ships. It is also worth mentioning, you can't win. It is impossible to win. As the games motto/slogan says "Everybody Dies". The whole object is to loose the 'least' by having less casualties.  For each 1 million citizens killed, your continent gains 2 points, for every 1 million citizens killed on your continent, you loose 1 point. The game is easy to grasp but can be a bit challenging at times and difficult to use. It does take time to learn, but hey, its really cheap on sales and what isn't good about nuking the ♥♥♥♥ out of Africa? TL;DR11/10 would nuke Africa multiple times again.

												DEFCON is perhaps the only game which allows you to commit a global-scale nuclear genocide...and award you for it.Although simple in design, this is probably one of those rare games which have a "timeless" stamp on them. The slick, elegant graphics that pay homage, or rather, "totally worship" classic films such as Dr. Strangelove and WarGames, serve their purpose in a most appealing way. You may only see one screen in the vanilla game, but it is more than enough for the sheer beauty DEFCON is.Background music also deserves massive praise - it is simple, minimal, ambient, atmospheric, yet haunting. Haunting is the right word. It is the perfect setting for this game. Hearing a distant, muffled cry of a woman somewhere in the background while the screen is coldly informing you that you have you just erased millions of lives is an experience no other game offers. As for the gameplay, the most important thing, after all - do not be fooled by the looks of the game. It is a complex strategy title, a unique one in the bunch, which doesn't fall back behind any of its genre "collegues". There are many ways to commit nuclear holocaust, many little details and tactical manuveurs to be had - I admit myself that I'm still quite an unskilled player, but seeing the ways I was eradicated of the map and reading several walkthroughs, I can confrim - this game is truly a strategy game.Only real flaw of the game is its community, or to be precise, the lack of it.I had to wait for more than half an hour, sometimes, to fine an open spot in a game. Creating your own game can result in even more time spent.However, there are still players, you just need to be a tad bit lucky.In the end, I recommend this game - if you're interested in an unique experience, picking this up on a sale day is no wrong doing.

												One of those games that is both well programmed and well made to make nuclear war just another giddy joyride.The game focuses on a world during the late 70's and early 80's, where nuclear war is taking place, and up to 6 nations can declare into it, the nations include The European union (and several other nations not currently in the EU) The USSR, (A and some parts of Kazakhstan) Asia (Not Ocenia, Australia, or Mongolia) Lain America (Not including Cuba) Africa, and North America including Canada and the United States.In order to win, you must get more points than your foes, you get points by killing each millions of people with your ICBMs, there are multiple modes, but I'm covering the stock mode.The game starts at Defcon 5, you can place Radar on your territory, Nuclear Silos (Which will shoot down enemy bombers and fighters as well as launch ICBM) and finally, military air bases that can launch Bombers with nuclear capacity, and fighters.Also during Defcon 5, you can place ships, either battleships, which focus on fighting directly at sea, Subs, which can scan the area and launch nuclear missiles (However said launch will let the rest of the players see them) and Carries, that can't fight, but can use depth charges to take out said Subs, and can also launch bombers and fighter jets. (Each jet also has some small amount of radar to let you see enemy silos and Radar)You can only place units until Defcon 3, when battle becomes more intense, and you are allowed to send jets into enemy territory to scan for military bases and whatnot.After getting to Defcon 1, Nuclear weapons are permitted, and can be launched by Bomber, Silo (Which will prevent the Silo from protecting against incoming jet, bomber, or ICBM.)After you or them launch, the entire game flashes with the warning that one of the players dared to go launch nuclear missiles, and silos (Or Subs) That are launching them will be revealed to the world, and nuclear missiles will launch, but will only be seen if it's under a general radar of a team..A nuclear missile will destroy Radar in one hit, and air bases in two, and silos in three, also destroying half of that building's current housed warfare. (Be it be bombers/fighters or ICBMs)A missile, hitting a city, will kill half it's living population, which is usually a a couple million each hit, depending on where you strike. Despite a majority of the community is gone, the game is still here, unlike TF2, which is aimed at multiplayer play, this can be played with well programmed AI, of which aren't generic, and actually are quite hard at times.The achieves, however, can't actually be attained form fighting bots, so you have to play online to actually get them, but due to a dwindling community, it's quite hard to find those players, so try to get friends to play if you want to competition against an actual person.

You play as a general in an underground bunker, and make the decision to launch the missiles to (hopefully) kill more of them than they kill of you.PROS:+Deceptively easy to learn, difficult to master.+Absolutely minimal graphics requirements. Even in victory, you take one look at the total civilian deaths and feel empty inside.+Highly strategic game with an emphasis on placement of your bases (including radar, airbases, and missile silos). Poor placement leads to an easy defeat.CONS-Not for everyone. Some people can't handle the long, slow gameplay many games stretch out to, while others simply don't like strategy games (perhaps even on this scale).DEFCON holds a dear place in my heart, and is best played with all of the lights off, in a room where the only light comes from the monitor fortelling the end of civilization as we know it.

												This game is scarier than any of the horror games I've played- and it's not even a horror game! It's a simulation/strategy game about nuclear war, if you couldn't figure that out. You nuke the enemies' cities to earn a better score, and if the enemy nukes your cities (or destroys your units), then you lose points and stuff. The team with the highest score wins. It is a very dark game, for example: you can hear people crying sometimes and when a city is hit with a nuclear missile it shows the amount of people who were killed, it's especially frightening if it's a place you live in or if loved ones live there. The soundtrack is FANTASTIC, and sets the mood of the game PERFECTLY. I'm not very good at playing the game, but you don't even have to play! You can set up AI battles, and I sometimes hop on and watch one. They're actually pretty entertaining, and the AI is good in my book. Speaking of setting things up, it's very customizable. A single game can be very time consuming if played in real-time, and the nukes take a while to reach its target. Also, when I played in real-time (and quit after ten minutes i dont have time for that) I felt like I was the one giving the OK to launch the nukes and responsible for the millions of deaths I caused, not to mention feeling guilty about my cities getting exploded by the enemies. Overall, it's a pretty good game, but it can be difficult and is very dark. Unfortunately, the last update was sometime in 2014, so it seems that the developers have stopped updating it, however it feels finished and the price is reasonable for $9.99 USD. 8/10 - Solid game. But why is it scarier than the horror games I've played? That's because it can actually happen...

There are a lot of people having technical difficulties getting the game to actually function, but I haven't had any, and I'm running on a laptop. This is a fun low-demand game for people with cheaper PCs (I've heard it doesn't run on Macs but I'm not certain), but it isn't without its flaws. The game itself is fine and allows for a large amount of strategy and seems like one of those games you might play at an office, having a LAN party (It even has a stealthy office mode, in case the boss shows up), much like DOOM might have had, back in the day. The soundtrack leaves a little to be desired, but from what I understand, this game is highly moddable, though I don't use mods myself, so it seems like an easy change to make. Cons about this game is that, due to its age, there are not as many people playing anymore, and those who are are often far more experienced than your typical new player. Fortunately, this game is just as much fun in single player, allowing for a maximum of 6 players (plus spectators) in any game. There is a variety of game modes that can either stress fast decision making, diplomacy, aggression, or defense, meaning that there's always something else to try. If you can find a few friends to play this with, it's definitely worth a few game nights, since alliances can be made or broken on the spot, in game. DEFCON does not support in-game voice chat, though, so maybe run skype in the background. All in all, I give this game an 8.5/10

												NO FIGHTING IN THE WAR ROOMDEFCON is the second title from the brilliant independent company Introversion Software. It's a haunting and daunting game, where you are charged with the offensive forces of a portion of the world as a timer ticks down the stages of the US Defense Readiness Condition system. (5 is peacetime, 1 is nuclear war.)Gameplay consists of placing buildings such as radar sites, missile silos and air bases in your chosen territory and assembling your naval fleets with aircraft carriers, battleships and submarines. As the DEFCON clock ticks down, air and naval combat is enabled, then at DEFCON 1 nuclear strikes from silos or submarines is authorized against population centers and military installations. Your overall goal is to lose the least; to get away with less civilian megadeaths (millions of deaths) than the other combatants. Hence the game's slogan: EVERYBODY DIES.The macabre nature of gameplay combined with the chilling NORAD-command-screen aesthetic and melancholy music makes for a tense game pretty much every time you play. Especially if you're not terribly good at it like me. That, and the main menu is nifty and there's good mod/AI support.Anyone who is interested in the Cold War or wants a dark twist to their RTS gaming owes it to themselves to at least try this game.

The game also feels like it's got a mind of its own, i mean, it started off in 1920x1080 fullscreen mode, but when i changed some of the options it "reverted to safe mode", a mode oddly enough which it had never been in up to that point. So i reversed the few options i had changed in order to start the process again and see what was going on, but sadly from there on out i was never able (or allowed it seems) to get back into 1920x1080 fullscreen. Having only bought the game for 0.59p i can't say I'm feeling the loss, but then no one in their right mind would pay for a bad experience would they?... i guess if you are a liberal you would, but for the rest of us who aren't mentally defective liberals we don't want to. If they were to update this with modern graphics and a command center view which isn't done in retro Atari 2bit style, then i might take a look at that game, otherwise, if you are looking to get this, you'll probably only play a couple of 'rounds' and then think why you just wasted your pennies on it.UPDATE: I decided to look for mods, since mods make the world go round an all. Ok so i discovered a mod called 'SatCon' which does away with the Atari darkness, and gives a proper view as if from space with the landmasses coloured and the seas represented in blue. Much better right away. Here is the link for the mod:http://www.introversion.co.uk/defcon/mods/All you have to do is make a folder in the main DEFCON folder called Mods (if there wasn't one already like in my case), then unpack/unzip the mod you downloaded into that, then start the game up and choose Mods from the menu, then activate that mod and job done. 												DEFCON, in simple terms, is a simulator/game where you can destroy entire countries and continents by using nuclear weapons to decimate populations and cities whilst watching them burn. You can choose to be either North America (Canada, USA), South America (All South American countries), Africa (All African countries), Asia (Most Asian countries and far east countries), Europe (All European countries) or just Russia (Just russia, duh). There is a DEFCON timer, in which it starts from DEFCON 5 all the way to DEFCON 1, signalling nuclear war. The DEFCON system is a US defence and readiness condition system in which state the military should be readied at, depending on the current condition, five to one. Slowly or very quickly depending on what speed you want it on, the DEFCON level will drop until it reaches DEFCON 1 and nuclear war will begin. The game is based on a film called Wargames (1983) and is about a hacker who gains control of NORAD's nuclear missiles and threatens nuclear war. The GUI and game is very similar to Wargames' control systems and computer simulations. In order to start the game you need to select one of the continents, you can place down radars, missile silos and airbases. Each one of these has a certain strategic importance. Radars can detect incoming nuclear missiles from nuclear submarines or land based silos and show their trajectories. Airbases have the ability to launch fighter and bombers to city targets or fleets of ships in the oceans, the bombers can also drop one nuke onto a city or military target. Silos obviously have the ability to fire up to 10 missiles anywhere at a target. Silos can also become air defence systems in which they will shoot down incoming missiles, fighters and bombers within their range. There is also the ability to place fleets of ships (nuclear missile equipped submarines, battleships and aircraft carriers). Submarines can attack ships on the surface of the sea and sink them and can also fire nukes at cities within a shorter range than silos but they are more stealthy. Battleships are an all-round ship, they can attack all kinds of ships including aircraft. Aircraft carriers can launch nuke bombers to cities or military targets and attack them and launch fighter jets to attack ships. It is also worth mentioning, you can't win. It is impossible to win. As the games motto/slogan says "Everybody Dies". The whole object is to loose the 'least' by having less casualties. For each 1 million citizens killed, your continent gains 2 points, for every 1 million citizens killed on your continent, you loose 1 point. The game is easy to grasp but can be a bit challenging at times and difficult to use. It does take time to learn, but hey, its really cheap on sales and what isn't good about nuking the ♥♥♥♥ out of Africa? TL;DR11/10 would nuke multiple times again.

												WARNING: If you don't like giant explosions, war, nuclear weapons, or even the thought of committing mass genocide, then stop reading and get another game, like Galacon 2. However, if you like the former, then keep reading.Imagine being in an underground bunker, for say the United States, and there was a massive series of crisis that unfolded. Your clock ticks ever so slowly towards zero as Defcon 4 approaches. You start mobilizing your navy to try to defend your coasts against the inevitable assault against your country. You establish airfields and silos along the coastline and close to your cities, so you can protect them. It's Defcon 3 now, and the enemy started to mobilize their forces against each other. Only 5 minutes later a battle fleet has come into radar range of your fleet. Your fleets start to open fire, aircraft carriers launching bombers and fighters while your battleships launch cruise missiles and fire massive guns at your enemy. It's Defcon 2 now, and you are being attacked from the east and the west. Finally, it reaches DEFCON 1. You hear a woman crying in the background, knowing that she is disturbed greatly by the outcome of the events beforehand. You start opening your missile silos and launch multiple nukes at your nearest enemy: Europe. Luckily, you had an alliance with South America, who was helping you defend against the enemy assault. However, 10 minutes after you launch a salvo of nukes, your radar detects a nuke heading towards your country. That nuke becomes 2, then 3, then 6. Your radar detects even more nukes coming from Europe. You then detect a strategic missile sub off the East coast, but you destroy it with depth charges before it can fire. However, you then see a wave of nuke bombers coming from Europe. Your defenses are spread thin, and only 2 bombers were shot down before they fired. You then launch almost every nuke you have against Europe, only to realize that Russia has also fought against you. You launch your last nukes at Russia, only to watch 10 nukes land in Europe successfully, of the 25 you have launched. You then admit defeat as tens of nukes tear your country apart in a glorious storm of radiation and fire, killing almost every human left in your country.This is what you will experience in DEFCON. What I didn't mention in this, is the atmosphere is EXTREMELY effective at what it does. The occasional woman crying in the background, and the ominous, and slightly creepy, soundtrack just makes you feel remorse, even dread, just for launching fake nukes at a fake country. Yeah, it's THAT powerful of an experience. Hell, the game even comes with a manual on how to survive a nuclear war.

												This game is based on War games, and I have to say I always had a good interest. After a few hours of play, I have to say I am not really that impressed. It seems that it appeals to a sense of nostalgia, although I do love the simplicity of the strategy and the overall design. The music is wonderful and ambient, it really sets the mood and to me is probably one of the stongest elements of the game. The game itself was part of a bundle and so the price I pretty good in terms of value, however the problems for me are with the gameplay itself. The tutorials do give you the very bare bones basics, but really does not prepare you that well for what is coming. I enjoy a good learning curve and a good difficulty, but honestly I cannot say that the tutorials really helped that much. I think the problem with this game is that the strategy element is during the placement phase and if you place your units and elements incorrect at the beginning then the game is as good as lost, no matter how well you play after that. I had to laugh at one bug, which I screenshotted, I had won a game, and was waiting for the victory timer, after the timer ran out the scores changed, giving me a nice loss. I guess there really are no winners in war. This game for a casual player like myself, has a learning curve that is just to steep, and gets pretty repetitive pretty fast. I'll bet if you are in to deep strategy games and were to read though pages of guides and websiges for how to best counter and place units etc then you may get a lot more out of this game, But I just cannot spend time doing that at the moment, I may take a look at a later date when I have time to look through some guides, and I'm sure the multiplayer element may be more fun.I found the most fun for me was watching the rolling demo's and predicting who would win, the music is great as an ambient background noise, it was actually quite relaxing, I can see me watching some of those when I don't feel like actually playing any games myself. Overall I perhaps expected too much, but this one just wasn't for me, not at the moment anyway.

												Gobal Thermonuclear War.  Mutually Assured Destruction.  In the final war, nobody will win, and everybody dies, but in DEFCON perhaps you can lose the least.Taking inspiration from the 1983 film Wargames, you take control of a global superpower on the verge of the nuclear apocalypse.  Deploy your silos, radars, and submarines, defend your territory while blowing the other guys away forever.The game takes about 15 minutes if played on the fastest speed or up to 6 hours to complete if left on the slowest setting.  You can jump back and forth between them as you see fit, allowing you to give orders in very slow time without being overwhelmed, then speed up time to see the results of your actions.Boiled down to its core, this is a game of chicken.  Should you strike first, hoping to cripple your opponents chance for retaliation?  Or should you wait, attempt to outlast their attacks, and deliver your own killing blow when they’ve been depleted?  Do you send your naval forces aggressively towards the enemy coastline or keep them close to home in order to defend?  It takes them a long time to travel the whole ocean, so your decision will be a lasting one.The music is somber and funereal, as it should be in a game about dealing instant fiery death to untold millions of people.  The graphics capture that cold, heartless, military wargame style perfectly.There is no campaign to work through, no storyline to finish.  There’s just the single scenario of global destruction to play again and again, though depending on the numerous modifiable game settings and which continent you play, they will always turn out different.  You can make it so losing your own citizens is weighed more heavily than killing others, or vice versa.  You can make alliances unbreakable, or change the number of units each team will have.  There is endless replayability here.It’s a good thing that this scenario is no longer in the forefront of our minds like it was in the 60′s, 70′s, 80′s, and even 90′s.  We no longer fear this afternoon of destruction, where the entire world is wiped out due to a domino effect of retaliation.  Yet it is still very much possible in today’s world.  Nuclear arms are still held by numerous countries the world over.DEFCON is an interesting little strategy game with some really good decision-making opportunities.  This would be a perfect game for a LAN party full of deal-making and backstabbing, but playing it alone is a rather somber experience.

												DEFCON borrows some of its lore and most of its appearance from portions of the movie WarGames. The multi player scene is still active, and it is very easy to find open matches with all kinds of different settings. Personally, I prefer playing against the CPU, much like in the movie. The map is fairly accurate, depicting the geopolitical era of the Cold War. Implementing orders to your units can sometimes be confusing and inadequate, but with enough attempts, you become used to the interface, and will be able to do all of the game's strategical requirements. What is most valuable in DEFCON is the replay ability. Certainly, each match has an ending, but the game truly shines when you play it repeatedly; alone or online. Winning is not easy. Several things must go right, and occur at specific moments in order to be successful. Because of these timing issues, sometimes you will win or lose depending on how quickly or how slowly your units execute orders in conjunction with timers. Nuking cities and other strategic locations doesn't exactly feel like you are killing people. There isn't very much tension. It all just feels like you are clicking around on the map and delegating orders. The feeling that lives are actually being lost is not truly present. At the end of each match, you will be shown a small statistics screen with how much of the enemy population you have killed, how many of your population have been killed, and so on. Each match takes between 15 to 20 minutes to complete, and it often feels like each instance ends abruptly without much of a climax or excitement in the confrontations. The entire atmosphere is very cold and impersonal. Setting up a new single player match means you will have to go into the advanced settings every single time in order to change a few options to single player mode. The default (which can't be permanently altered) is set to multi player, broadcasting your match as public. This is quite annoying and should not have been programmed as such. I am certain that there are many DEFCON players that prefer single player mode and this preference should not be hindered by permanently set options from the developers. The longevity of DEFCON is dependent entirely on the player's interest in its short matches, be it single player or multi player. Besides your initial location on the match, it feels like every single match is played almost exactly the same, with very little occurring differently or alternatively. The strategies necessary to play this game are limited and basic, regardless of whether you win or lose. The only major change as you become better at the game is that you will begin winning, but this does not mean each match will be played differently, or go through a different turn of events. As repetitive as it is, there is a small amount of entertainment gained from playing DEFCON for more than three or so matches at a time. The gaming experience quickly becomes dull, repetitive, tiresome, and almost identical to every other match you play. DEFCON is best played in short bursts in order to preserve its replay ability. Seriously lacking in variety, this diversion is suited for fast breaks and brief encounters.DEFCON is mediocre.

												The following review was copied straight from my review at http://officialvghc.com/vghc-reviews/defcon-pc-review/#.UpROXsTmN_Q, because I'm too lazy to write a new one.I’m a huge sucker for the movie WarGames. So when I found out about the game DEFCON, I naturally couldn’t resist. Finally I could play the “WarGame”.How wrong I was.Being a gamer, I naturally was like “eh, tutorials, I don’t need those.” However, this is one of those games where you do need those without them telling you. And boy is that tutorial lengthy. So, 6 chapters and 30 minutes later I was thrown into the 7th chapter: use what you’ve learned to defeat this extremely-easy AI. Oh wait, did we say easy? We meant hard. as. ♥♥♥♥. Oh, and I still really didn’t grasp the game.Well, that was demoralizing.Thing is, officially DEFCON is a multiplayer game. It’s possible to play against the AI, but that’s even harder than in the tutorial. When you keep in mind that one can’t complete the tutorial because the AI is too hard, you get really depressing ideas about what the AI in the actual game is like.But it’s a multiplayer game right? So why not just face other players? Yeah, about that… There aren’t any other players, really. You’re going to need a friend to play, if they’re willing to play this ♥♥♥♥ at all.Thing is, the game was “inspired by the infamous 1983 movie WarGames.” So, naturally, I had big expectations. I knew that I probably wasn’t going to play against Joshua, but still. When you make a game inspired by a movie about computer from the MS-DOS era, at least make the graphics resemble that era. Don’t make elaborate maps with perfect borders – make them liney and polygonal. Don’t make elaborate icons – make sure that the game looks like it could run on MS-DOS.So what are you supposed to do? Well, the game starts off at DEFCON 5. It’s time to build a military defense system. Place missile silos, create fleets, create military airports, place radars. You know – a defense system.Many actions don’t unlock until you hit a certain DEFCON level. For example, you can’t dispatch planes until DEFCON 3, and nukes can of course only be launched at DEFCON 1.Now this is the point where you expect hell to be unleashed. Nope, that’ll take a while. You can use missiles to explode nukes in the air (because the radioactive material totally won’t fall on your territory if that happens above land), but it takes a while for those nukes to come. You can try to strike first – but if you’re Europe and your enemy is North America then you’re screwed because you’ll need nuclear submarines, and once those get above the surface they get destroyed because they’re suddenly visible.It’s also really not clear what the goal of the game is. My best guess is “destroy the enemy’s cities” – but that’s damn near impossible because I needed all my nukes to destroy New York (I had like 40 nukes). So what then? “Destroy the enemy’s defense systems”? That might be possible. I’d rather just know instead of having to guess though.I feel incredibly let down by this game. It’s just not fun. There’s also some kind of alliance feature for when you play with 3 or 4 players, but I didn’t get to test it out because I didn’t grasp the game and only have one friend to play it with (and he uses the demo).Know what I miss most? The command prompt. That stuff was awesome about the movie. It would’ve allowed for some great references as well. A missed opportunity.So, all in all, this game is a huge letdown. It fails to deliver what looks like a fun game, and falls short on many aspects. Too bad, guys, too bad.Score: 4/10

												A good majority of strategy wargames out there focus on the high action or grand spectacle of seeing tanks and troops move in sweeping engagements. Not DEFCON. This takes the pure strategy approach to Mutually Assured Destruction, putting you in the seat of the head of state who gets to sit safely in some bunker while they watch the body count rise in the millions. It's very challenging, but also haunting when you really realize what you're doing exactly.This is one of those simple games that is simple to get the concept of, but it takes a long time to really get the hang of it. Anyone expecting a grand victory for moderate work is going to be disappointed, as fortunes can change quickly from overwhelmingly good to horrifically bad in one salvo or even one white-hot nuke detonation. There's some initial challenge when you are learning the control interface, but with practice you can quickly issue orders and begin to focus more on strategy. The best comparison I can come up with is the ages-old game of Chess. It's simple, it lacks flash and thunder, but if you are willing to apply your braincells, you can orchestrate victory for your nation. Whether you feel good for laying waste to millions of civilians or not is a whole other question...

												Overall, I liked this game because it was fun to go back to the Cold War era and relive the atmosphere of 1980s graphics and possible nuclear annihilation. But this game barely makes onto the recommended side, because after a few times playing it, you realize it's not that fun. It's really designed to be a multi-player game, and while you can have AI's to play against, I felt like there were issues with the balance between making it challenging and making it fun to play. It seems you can tweak and adjust every parameter in the game, so you can make it easier or harder, but I feel like it's a lazy way out of designing a game to just tell the user to set it up for themselves.
